message.content:
cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SY, cs.CR, cs.AI. 

This paper deals with the design of a system for opportunistic spectrum access, which involves sensing the availability of spectrum and accessing it without interfering with primary users. This topic is relevant to several sub-fields of computer science, including information theory (cs.IT), networking and internet architecture (cs.NI), systems and control (cs.SY), cryptography and security (cs.CR), and artificial intelligence (cs.AI). However, given the focus on sensing errors and the use of a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) formulation, cs.IT and cs.NI are the most likely sub-categories. The paper also discusses the interaction between the physical layer spectrum sensor and the MAC layer sensing and access strategies, which further supports the relevance of cs.NI. The other sub-categories are less likely but still plausible, as they may relate to specific aspects of the problem, such as robustness (cs.CR) or optimization (cs.AI).
